story: One of East Lothianrsquos original sports facilities lsquoHaddington Swimming Poolrsquo, as it was first known as, opened its doors in September .The much-loved site at the Aubigny Sports Centre consists of a four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool.Currently the facility welcomes about , bathers to the pool each week for swimming lessons, AquaFit classes, club training, school and public use.Operators enjoyleisure posted on Facebook: "After  years, Aubigny Sports Centres swimming pool hall is getting a well-earned facelt."The swimming pools and health suite will close on Tuesday for nine weeks to complete a refurbishment of the pool hall."Donrsquot worry, the rest of the sports centre will remain open for all your gym, fitness and sporting activities."The refurbishment will include both essential maintenance and interior deacutecor upgrades.The refurbishment plans include the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Inside the pool hall, following a complete drain of both pools, a light and bright ceiling covering will replace the outdated wood cladding.A new energy efficient lighting scheme will be fitted which will transform the look and feel of the facility for the benefit of all users.Furthermore, existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner  to complete the fresh new look.The final day of the works is scheduled to be Friday, June .Swimming lessons there are scheduled to resume on Monday, July .

title: families-flock-to-county-beaches-as-easter-holiday-temperatures-soar
story: After temperatures topped  degrees Celcius in many locations ndash including Haddington ndash on Easter Sunday, today was similarly sultry.As these pictures show, North Berwicks beaches were a popular choice for locals and visitors alike, with the golden sands at Yellowcraig and Gullane also busy.Sadly, the weather picture for the rest of the week is not quite so encouraging, although there will hopefully be some sunny periods tomorrow , but without the unseasonally high temperatures.

title: man-set-upon-by-group-of-15-people-on-north-berwick-high-street
story: The serious assaulthappened around at about .pm on High Street.Police received reports of a disturbance and on attendance a -year-old man was found with what they described as "signicant" facial injuries.He was taken to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh for treatment.Police inquiries have established thatthe victim was attacked by a group of about  people.Anyone who can help policein identying those involved is being asked to come forward.Detective Constable James Welsh from Lothians and Scottish Borders CID said: "This has been quite a large disturbance that left the victim with a number of painful injuries to his face."North Berwick High Street was likely to have still had a number of people coming and going from the area at this time of the evening and anyone who saw what happened and has yet to contact police should do so immediately."In addition, anyone who can provide any information that can help us identy those responsible is also urged to get in touch."Contact Lothians and Scottish Borders CID via  with information and quote incident number  of April . Alternatively, an anonymous report can be made to the charity Crimestoppers on   .

title: honest-lad-and-honest-lass-candidates-set-for-elections
story: Seeking election for  are: Claire Dougal,  Aidan Maguire,  Michael Morrison,  and Abbie Thomson, .Michael has served as an attendant for the past two years and Claire was also an attendant at last yearrsquos festival, supporting Honest Lad Conor Scott and Honest Lass Katie McLaren as part of the official party.Also throwing their hats into the ring this year are Aidan and Abbie, who are also delighted to be standing as candidates.The following polling stations are open for voting Friday: Brunton Hall concourse, am-pm Musselburgh Primary Care Centre, am to pm Musselburgh Museum, .am until pm Musselburgh East Community Centre, pm until pm Musselburgh Rugby Club, pm to pmWallyford Community Centre, pm to pm Whitecraig Community Centre, pm to pm.Each polling station is operated by members of festival organisers the Honest Tounrsquos Association and overseen by volunteers from the Rotary Club of Musselburgh and Old Musselburgh Club. At the end of the election, votes are counted by an independent team and supervised by a representative of each candidate.The four candidates are now working hard to canvas for the publicrsquos vote by selling membership cards costing pound throughout the community.Once purchased, these cards can then be presented at one of the listed polling stations on election day for votes to be cast.The result of the election will initially be declared within The Brunton to the candidates, their families, local councillors and the associationrsquos committee before being announced publicly from the outside balcony of the building at about pm.In traditional style, the new Honest Lad, Honest Lass and attendants will be paraded around the town in an open carriage led by the Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band. Everyone is welcome to go along to hear the announcement and help get the  Musselburgh Festival off to a great start.A disco will take place in Musselburgh Rugby Club which will be open from .pm, with entry pound.Alison Elgin, association president, said: ldquoWe have four excellent candidates and they are all working hard to canvas votes. We do all that we can to ensure that the election is as fair and transparent as is possible, and we are really proud that the people of Musselburgh vote for their Honest Lad and Honest Lass each year.ldquoPlans are well under way for Festival Week  with events which will hopefully appeal to everyone."This year we are working with Musselburgh Racecourse on their Community Race Day which will be held on Sunday, September . As a result of this, we can announce that, by voting in this yearrsquos election, you will be admitted free of charge to Musselburgh Racecourse on the day when you present your membership card which will be stamped at the polling station when you vote.This yearrsquos Musselburgh Festival will run from July  to .The candidates are:Claire DougalClaire, , was born and brought up in Whitecraig, attending Whitecraig Primary and Musselburgh Grammar Schools. She works at Pinkie Farm Shop as a general assistant. She has been a member of Musselburgh Crusaders Riding Club since she was  years old and won the youngest rider trophy at the age of . She has taken part in every Musselburgh rideout since she was eight years old and has participated in numerous fancy dress parades. She has also had the pleasure of attending numerous other townsrsquo rides and festivals over the last few years. Claire enjoys spending time with friends, family and her horse Ripper. She thoroughly enjoyed last year as an attendant, visiting local schools and businesses and representing Musselburgh in the Borders. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh in  after a fantastic year last year.Aidan MaguireAidan, , was a pupil at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh before attending St Davidrsquos High School in Dalkeith. During secondary school, he held part-time positions at TK Maxx and USC. On leaving school, he was appointed as an apprentice with Slight Joinery Ltd. Aidanrsquos interests include following national rugby and football teams as well as snowboarding, and he enjoys trying new sports.He has been a spectator of the festival, watching the rideouts and fancy dress parade with his family and friends. Aidan has a good understanding of the history behind the festival and feels that this is the right time to become more involvedMichael MorrisonMichael, , attended Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School. Originally living in Carberry, he moved to Musselburgh five years ago when his grandfather retired from his candle-making business. He has been involved in ious community activities since his primary school days, having been a member of the Boysrsquo Brigade, a piper with the Boysrsquo Brigade band and a member of Musselburgh Rugby Club. He played for Musselburgh both at club and district level, and has been involved with assisting the training of junior rugby players. For the past two years, he has had the honour of supporting past Honest Lad Jamie Cameron and Honest Lad Conor Scott as their attendant, and it is his ambition to become Honest Lad himself and to represent Musselburgh. His time as attendant has prepared him well for this responsibility. Michael is currently employed as a security guard. He recently gained his bus driving qualications and is keen to become a coach driver. He is looking forward to participating in the forthcoming festival and knows how enjoyable it can be for everyone.Abbie ThomsonAbbie, , has lived in Musselburgh all her le and attended Campie Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School, where she was a prefect in her fth and sixth year. Growing up, she attended Brownies at Pinkie School and Guides at Northesk. She is currently in her final year studying BScApplied Animal Science at Scotlandrsquos Rural University College and she is due to graduate in July. Abbie began riding at the age of  and was an active member of the local pony club. She spends most of her free time with her own horse, mucking out stables at a local livery yard or volunteering at the Riding for the Disabled Association. Having grown up watching the festival and taking part in the fancy dress parade when she was younger, Abbie is delighted to be a candidate for Honest Lass. She is looking forward to representing Musselburgh as part of the official party both at home and in the Borders.

title: former-cockenzie-power-station-site-about-to-be-put-on-open-market
story: East Lothian Council is preparing to put giant signs on the former Cockenzie Power Station land inviting potential customers to make a bid.The move comes just over a year after the council formally completed the purchase of the -acre coastline site.Public consultations on the future of the site, which includes a large area of communal land, known as the Greenhills, which is used by local communities and the former coal plant site and historic Waggonway land, were carried out over two years ago.The local authority produced a masterplan for the site based on the consultations, which it described as a ldquovision document for its future.However, neighbouring communities straddling the site have opposing views on its best future development.Prestonpans Community Council has lobbied for a cruise terminal at the former power station and the council has agreed to carry out an engineering study into its feasibility.In neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton, community councillors are keen to see the masterplan, which does not support a cruise port, adopted by the local authority.It sets out a range of ideas for the site, including the potential for a marina at the waterfront, business and economic sectors, and recreational land.Despite the investment into producing the masterplan and consulting the public, the only definite project confirmed for the site so far is an unmanned substation, which will bring offshore energy onto land for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd .ICOL, which are owned by Chinese State-owned company Red Rock, was granted permission for the substation after the Scottish Ministers called in its planning application shortly after East Lothian Council bought the land.The council confirmed earlier this month that is had agreed to sell part of the land to ICOL.A bid by local group the Battle of Prestonpans Heritage Trust to buy part of the land for its own heritable project has been rejected by the council.The council told the trust it had been advised against selling until ldquosuch time as the future of the whole site has been determined.Signs promoting the land for development are expected to go up on the site within the next few weeks after they were given planning approval.They will invite all enquiries about ldquoeconomic development opportunities on the site to get in touch via email.

title: opening-hours-slashed-at-three-tsbs-in-east-lothian
story: Dropping footfall has been blamed for the hours being cut at the bankrsquos branches in Haddington, North Berwick and Dunbar.The changes will come into force from the end of July and will not affect the Musselburgh TSB branch.A spokeswoman for TSB said that there had been a drop of eight per cent in customer transactions in Haddington, three per cent in Dunbar and one per cent in North Berwick.Currently, the branches in Dunbar, Haddington and North Berwick are all open from .am to .pm from Monday to Friday, with a lunch hour .-.pm.However, from the end of July, the TSB branch in Haddington will only be open Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, while the North Berwick branch will only be open between those hours on a Tuesday and Friday, and Dunbar will be open on a Monday and Thursday.Carol Anderson, branch distribution director for Scotland at TSB, said: ldquoOur customers use banking services in dferent ways and that is why we try to adapt our offer to deliver them the best possible service, however they choose to bank.ldquoThis means investment in both branches and digital channels.ldquoWith fewer people using [the branches], we are reducing the number of hours.ldquoOur TSB Partners will be working with our customers to support them as we make this change.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, felt it was disappointing to see a unit on High Street not being fully utilised.Mrs Swan said: ldquoI think all banks are making decisions about how they can best operate financially.ldquoThey must have worked out their best business case is to work two days a week.ldquoI suspect some of the customers will find it sufficiently inconvenient that they will switch banks. We, as a community council, are aware of lots of people who did switch from the Royal Bank of Scotland to Bank of Scotland [when Dunbarrsquos RBS closed last year].ldquoI think it is plainly unfortunate to have a unit on High Street that is not operational five days a week.

title: unpaid-work-for-man-caught-with-scissors-in-haddington
story: James Potter, of Kirk View, was caught with a pair of scissors while on the townrsquos Monkmains Road earlier this year.Potter, , pleaded guilty to the charge when he appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.Sherf John Cook decided to mark the offence by ordering Potter to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community.Potter admitted possessing a pair of scissors at Monkmains Road, Haddington, on March .

title: chance-for-public-to-have-a-look-at-major-plans-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: The plans ndash which are an update of proposals submitted a decade ago and would complement the existing golf course ndash also include a new driving range, a nine-hole golf course, a golf academy and practice facilities.Tony Thomas, who is representing Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd, which are behind the plans, visited the townrsquos community council ahead of the public exhibition, which takes place in the townrsquos Dunmuir Hotel between pm and pm tomorrow.Mr Thomas said alterations to the original plans, which were approved in , meant a new planning application had to be submitted.Now, amended plans have been drawn up, with hopes that a planning application could be with East Lothian Council, which would likely decide the fate of the proposals, by the autumn. Regardless of whether the plans are approved, golf will continue to be played on the -hole championship course.Mr Thomas, from East Lintonrsquos APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoIf we get the application in by September, something as relatively complex as this,we get permission this time next year we will be doing well.ldquoThe first houses would be a year later and then the clubhouse built by  for the clubhouse to opens its doors in .ldquoThe last houses would be  months on from that.The majority of the houses would be built towards Deer Park Cemetery, with about  units being built on the site of the current clubhouse.Under the plans, a new clubhouse would be built, with access coming from the A, and a nine-hole course built to the north-west, and a driving range to the east.The changes will mean a slight alteration to the layout of the course.The development will not include affordable housing as it is part of an enabling development. However, Mr Thomas stressed more than pound, would go to East Lothian Council in education contributions.Provisional designs for the properties, which are expected to be between three and five-bedroom in size, will be included in display boards at the exhibition.Details regarding the size of the hotel are still being worked out but historically the proposal was for a building with between  and  rooms.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, felt there were issues which could be addressed to enhance the proposals.She said: ldquoI just feel a sense of disappointment that the developers, who have such a wonderful opportunity, do not seem to take the opportunity to build more contemporary, innovative housing. That is my regret. It is a fantastic site but the sense of what we are going to get is a repeat of the Cala homes at Beveridge Row.Mrs Swan also noted a lot of people used the land at Deer Park for recreation.She said a previous public meeting, when the community council was consulting about East Lothian Councilrsquos local development plan, had highlighted a desire for improved connections throughout the town.She added: ldquoThe public meeting said it was really, really important to ensure there are really good pedestrian and cycle links back into the town wherever possible.

title: north-berwick-institution-sula-ii-is-retired
story: The Sula II, a much-loved wooden passenger boat, has ceased her summer tours around the Bass Rock and neighbouring islands after more than four decades of sailings.The clinker-built vessel is making her way to Southampton after being sold by owner Duncan MacRae.Mr MacRae, who purchased the vessel about  months ago, said: ldquoThe Sula II is a very old vessel and will struggle to comply with new safety regulations coming into force next year from the MCA .ldquoAs I take safety very seriously, I had the chance to sell the Sula II and she has now moved down to Southampton.ldquoSula III has now been ordered and purpose-built in Scotland to the highest modern standards and will be operational by next Easter.ldquoFor this season I am just about to secure the use of another vessel to keep the excellent Bass Rock sailings available for the public.The boat was originally purchased in the s by legendary North Berwick boatman and fisherman Fred Marr, who had been working on passenger launches from North Berwick throughout the s and s.She was the second boat he had bought for the purpose of tours, the first onebeing slightly old with a paraffin engine, so it was sold and Sula II replaced it.Pat Macaulay, Fredrsquos daughter, said: ldquoMy father purchased Sula II in  after seeing an advert in the Fishing News. This boat was originally called the Janet and was built in Norfolk.ldquoThe name Sula was chosen because it is the Latin name for the gannet, the bird that made Bass Rock a world-renowned bird sanctuary.The boat took tourists and locals out to sea from North Berwick on the Bass Rock tours under the Marr family up until , when Fredrsquos son Chris retired after  yearsrsquo sailing.Fred himself had retired in . He passed away in  and there is a plaque in his memory at North Berwick harbour.Sula II has seen many celebrities and dignitaries over her years, including Prince Charles, Brigitte Bardot, Sir David Attenborough, Alan Titchmarsh and Bill McLaren.Pat, who now lives on the Isle of Lewis, said: ldquoI have been contemplating for some time putting together a scrapbook of memories, photos, thoughts and reminisces from the many hundreds of people who enjoyed boat trips aboard Sula II over the years.ldquoSula II is etched into my heart and bloodstream, as is Bass Rock, itrsquos a very special place.To get in touch with Pat with memories from the Sula II, email patandthesula@gmail

title: long-serving-nursery-nurse-praised-as-she-retires
story: Susan Walker stepped down from her role at Macmerry Primary School shortly before the schools broke up for the Easter break.Jenner Welsh, who works at the school, said: ldquoSusan is known for her love of children, patience, organisation, kind manner and her commitment to the children and their families.ldquoShe has seen many colleagues come and go within the school and nursery and made many special friends along the way.ldquoSusan leaves us to embark on some travel, spend time with her family and take time to enjoy her many hobbies.ldquoShe will also be the newest member of the lsquoladies who lunch clubrsquo made from previous Macmerry retired staff.ldquoWe all wish her a well-deserved, long and enjoyable retirement.Susan lives to the east of Haddington with her husband.

title: drive-thru-coffee-shop-at-gateside-thought-to-be-starbucks-approved
story: Plans for a drive-thru coffee shop at Gateside West were given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council last week.The plans were lodged by Euro Garages Ltd, which is also behind the plans to transform the former Raceland karting centre, near Gladsmuir, into a roadside services hub.Starbucks are not named as applicants but within documents included in the Haddington planning application is a drawing labelled as lsquoStarbucks sitersquo.A spokeswoman for the coffee shop giants was tight-lipped as to whether they had any involvement with the proposals.She told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom afraid we arenrsquot able to comment on planning applications at this point in time.Plans for the coffee shop ndash which would be open seven days a week, from am to pm, and employ about  members of staff ndash were discussed by the townrsquos community council last month.They raised concerns about the noise generated by vehicles visiting the business.East Lothian Council has now given planning permission with a condition stating that an ldquoacoustic barrier has to be created between the boundary of the site and neighbouring houses.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was hopeful the development would not impact upon similar businesses in the town centre.She said: ldquoIt might get more passing trade or trade from people who live up there [but]I would not specically go up there for a cup of coffee.There will be parking for  vehicles, including two disabled bays, as well as an electrical charging unit and spaces for bicycles.While drawings included in the application show more than  seats inside the shop.The plans were discussed by Haddington Business Community Partnership , which met last Tuesday.David Diggory, a member of HBCP who has run Diggoryrsquos Coffee Shop on Haddington High Street for nearly seven years, was confident that the introduction of another coffee shop-type business would not have a detrimental impact on his own business.He said: ldquoMy opinions obviously donrsquot necessarily reflect the whole of the group but I do kind of feel it is more competition for the likes of Costa Coffee [which has a cafe in the townrsquos Tesco] than myself.ldquoThere have been many places opened up in and around High Street and people still find us.ldquoPeople that want to shop local and support local businesses will continue to do so.Originally, the site was identied for a pub restaurant as part of a wider plan for  houses and industrial units.However, developers failed to find anyone interested in the section of land earmarked for a pub restaurant and instead applied for permission for  houses to be built on the .-hectare site.East Lothian Council refused that planning permission  months ago before an appeal was dismissed by the councilrsquos local review body, which stressed the councilrsquos commitment to the land being used for employment.

title: port-seton-woman-receives-maundy-purse-from-the-queen
story: Dorothy Tervit was presented the purse of specially minted coins by Her Majesty The Queen at a ceremony before Easter weekend.Dorothy, from Laburnum Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoWhen the invitation came through in November, I thought it was a hoax!ldquoI thought lsquowhy on earth would Buckingham Palace be writing to me rsquoThe -year-old, who is a member of the local community choir, the local history society and Chalmers Memorial Church, was nominated by an anonymous supporter.The nominator has to be a Christian minister and the recipient is not allowed to know their identity, though Dorothy has some ideas.She said: ldquoUsing the process of elimination, I could make an educated guess.ldquoIrsquom so grateful, though, as the whole experience was absolutely wonderful ndash a real once-in-a-letime moment.The Royal Maundy refers to the service where the British Monarch distributes small purses full of coins called Maundy money as symbolic alms to the nominated recipients. It is a ceremony thought to date back to the Middle Ages and took place at St Georgersquos Chapel in Windsor.The coins are presented in two leather purses, a white one containing coins to the value of the same number of pence as the years of the monarchrsquos age, and a red purse containing a pound and a p coin.Dorothy was one of  recipients. As the Queen is  years old, there are  female recipients and  male recipients, as well as  pence worth of special silver coins in one of the purses.The other purse presented included a commemorative pound coin marking the th anniversary of Queen Victoriarsquos birth.Dorothy attended the ceremony last week with her husband Tom.She added: ldquoThe Queen was so gracious, I felt undeserving. We werenrsquot allowed to speak to her, as per the rules, but she had such a warm smile for everyone in line for the purse.

title: cinema-planned-along-with-holiday-lodges-at-archerfield
story: Caledonian Heritable is keen to further develop Archerfield via a dozen two-bedroom cabins, as well as extending Fletcherrsquos Cottage Spa and creating a cinema and additional conference facilities. If approved, two new homes would also be built on the sitersquos eastern boundary, near Dirleton.A supporting statement included in a planning application to East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe Bank of Scotland has been funding the previous expansion of Archerfield and in addition we have been contributing part of the monies raised from selling the [housing] plots at Archerfield.ldquoIt has been quite challenging financing Archerfield up to this point and it has been most beneficial that the [housing] plots at Kings Cairn are now managing to pay back some of the financial support given to us by the Bank of Scotland. To enable the proposed increase in the number of hotel bedrooms [cabins], extensions to the spa and laundry facilities etc, we need to give the bank further comfort to continue supporting our ambition to build Archerfield into Scotlandrsquos premier hotel accommodation with a top-of-the-range spa, golf courses, conference facilities, cinema etc.ldquoThe bank has security over all the property and land at Archerfield but we now need them to extend our facility to allow us to finance the poundm projected costs.If given the green light, the project would also result in further jobs being created with  per cent more staff in line to be employed.Tom Drysdale, who lives in nearby Dirleton, is chairman of Gullane Area Community Council. He said there were concerns about the proposals, particularly regarding the two properties off Manse Road.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoDirleton Village Association has a very strong view on the matter and is supported by the community council.ldquoThis is part of a much bigger planning application, which involves new additional facilities in the Archerfield Links golfing estate, a signicant number of holiday lodges and aroom.ldquoThe community is not concerned about any of these items, other than two house lodges, right beside the village green in Dirleton. There is a very strong feel that this is completely inappropriate.ldquoThe proposal is to build two big two-storey houses, which would simply not fit into the village environment.Set in  acres, the Archerfield Estate is home to two golf courses and a iety of accommodation styles to rent, including grade one-listed Archerfield House.There is also a cafe, deli, food market, gt shop, bar and microbrewery at Archerfield Walled Garden.

title: 110000-boost-for-musselburgh-charitys-work
story: The funding to the Bridges Centre, awarded over three years, will go towards the salary costs of a full-time personal development worker to deliver a programme of inidual and small group support to --year-olds.This will help young people develop their skills and aspirations for the future as the service seeks to build their emotional resilience and help them create positive relationships, enabling them to achieve their full potential.The grant, which was allocated through Children in Needrsquos Main Grants Programme, is its first funding allocation of the year, with additional cash-aid being distributed to projects across the UK throughout .Jim Boyle, chief executive of the Bridges Project, which is based on Musselburghrsquos Bogpark Road, said: ldquoWersquove been receiving funding from BBC Children in Need now for the last  years and, in that time, have been able to make a dference to hundreds of young peoplersquos lives.ldquoWersquore delighted that wersquoll be able to continue this for another three years in collaboration with our partners in education, social work, health and the voluntary sector.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children in Need, said: ldquoWe are delighted to fund the work of the Bridges Project and look forward to seeing the dference that this grant will make to children and young people across the region.Simon Antrobus, BBC Children in Needrsquos chief executive, added: ldquoAs always, thanks must go to our generous supporters and fundraisers. We are only able to make these much-needed awards because of them.In East Lothian and Midlothian, BBC Children in Need is currently funding nine projects to a value of pound,.Across Scotland, it has more than pound. million invested in projects making a positive dference to the lives of disadvantaged young people.For information on how to apply for funding, visit bbc pudsey grants

title: Christopher Brookmyre on the books that shaped him
story: Christopher Brookmyre, novelistFavourite book you read as childI was raised on Roald Dahl. I warmly remember my mum reading Charlie And The Chocolate factory to my sister and me last thing at night, and leaving us on clf-hanger endings, like when Charlie opens the bar of chocolate he got for his birthday. However, the Dahl book I re-read over and over was Danny The Champion Of The World, which I would disappear into on miserable rain-lashed afternoons. It was about prejudice, class and bullies, kindling in my young heart a burning sense of injustice that made Danny and his fatherrsquos revenge so sweet. It was also the first heist story I ever read, so the seeds of books such as Want You Gone and The Sacred Art Of Stealing were sown there.What was the first book that made an impact on you I was utterly bereft when I finished The Restaurant At The End Of the Universe, by Douglas Adams. Seriously, I had this profound sense of loss at how it ended and the fact that there was no more to come. I was in love with these characters and with Adamsrsquo galaxy, and at the age of  too naiumlve to realise that another book would be on its way soon enough. This in turn led to a moment of unconfined joy in John Menzies on Princes Street a couple of years later when I discovered a paperback of Le, The Universe And Everything.Which books have made you laugh or cry Long before we were married, I drove my we crazy on our first holiday together by reading Catch . She had never seen someone convulsed with laughter reading a book, never mind had to share a bed with one. Jeff Torringtonrsquos Swing Hammer Swing and Harry Pearsonrsquos The Far Corner also had me helpless with laughter. At the other end of the emotional scale, I was reduced to a blubbering, snottery wreck by the end of Philip Pullmanrsquos The Amber Spyglass.Favourite character Ford Prefect from The Hitch-Hikerrsquos Guide To The Galaxy. He was my inspiration for Jack Parlabane. I loved his combination of hedonistic abandon, unflappable equanimity and cynical weariness, often expressed simultaneously. He has a charming ability to wander into perilous situations and effortlessly make them much worse, all the while staying just wary enough of the danger.Least favourite genreldquoLiterary fiction, partly because the type of critic who uses the term would also deny that it is a genre, and partly because I am bemused by the implication that other types of fiction are not literary. Which is not to say that a book being described as literary fiction would put me off reading it, but just because a book does not belong within an easily defined genre doesnrsquot mean it is without its own tropes and conventions.Book you wish yoursquod writtenObviously, having penned a couple of Harry Potters and the Da Vinci Code would be a nice place to be, but I donrsquot think many writers would ever genuinely wish they had written someone rsquos book. Itrsquos like wishing yoursquod had someone rsquos children. At most there are books that I am glad somebody  had to go to the colossal bother of taking on, such as Neal Stephensonrsquos Baroque Cycle. I still find it hard to believe that those three vast and amazing novels were the work of one person.Book you think is overratedThe Bible. There are far better collections of Bronze-Age myths, and that whole messiah thing has been done to death.E reader or print Does anybody ever say they prefer an E reader  In an age when airlines are charging us extra to take a suitcase on holiday, my Kindle saves a lot of room in my luggage, but it will never be a treasured object.Where do you like to read Ideally, by a swimming pool where itrsquos  degrees centigrade in the shade, but devouring a book indoors when the rain is lashing the windows is still as cosy a feeling as it was when I was a kid.Last book you readAn advance proof of City Of Windows by Robert Pobi. It is a fantastic thriller about an astrophysicist applying his knowledge of maths and science to the hunt for a sniper who is working through a kill list, pulling off seemingly impossible shots. It takes place against a background of racial tension, conspiracy theories and paranoia, making it The Day Of The Jackal for Trumprsquos America.Favourite three novelsThis is a near-impossible question, but as an experiment I am going with the first three that leap to mind, to see what that tells me about myself. Swing Hammer Swing, the essence of Glasgow distilled into a single work, like a Billy Connolly routine that lasts for  pages. I re-read this every few years because it reminds me to up my game. Espedair Street by Iain Banks. Iain undoubtedly wrote more ambitious and accomplished novels, but this comic and melancholy tale of a Seventies supergroup from Paisley just transports me every time.The Baroque Cycle. You might say itrsquos cheating to chuck in a trilogy, especially one whose constituents are each around  pages, but I would argue that the books are inisible. This is the work I wish I had time to re-read, and one day I will allow myself that luxury.Favourite three non-fictionHiding the Elephant by Jim Steinmeyer. It is an enlightening history of the golden age of stage magic written lovingly by a man who designs illusions for magicians in Vegas.The Far Corner by Harry Pearson. This is my favourite book on football because it so warmly captures the relationship between the game and the communities around it. Also, it is rooted in the north-east of England, so those communities are defined by geography, not tribal affiliation. The Universe Next Door by Marcus Chown. I could have picked several books by Chown and by Michiu Kaku, but this is the one that really kicked off my theoretical physics habit, full of dizzying concepts brilliantly elucidated for those of us who donrsquot speak maths.Guilty pleasureI would normally argue that no reading pleasure should be a guilty one, but Pretty In Pink: The Golden Age of Teen Movies by Jonathan Bernstein probably qualies because itrsquos about a genre of films that its author himself would describe as a guilty pleasure. Nobody ought to have re-read this book as many times as I have. It is a waspishly funny nostalgia trip, one that gives enough flavour of certain Eighties movies that you donrsquot need to actually go back and watch them.Fallen Angel, by Christopher Brookmyre, is published by Little, Brown, priced pound.. He appears at the Boswell Book Festival on  May.

title: what-it-feels-like-to-be-a-chaplain-for-st-johnstone-fc
story: This is maybe my sixth or seventh season as the chaplain here. Before that I had been at Stirling Albion for a decade so Irsquove been doing this for a while now.Irsquom there mainly to be an ear or a sounding board. Itrsquos more than a social worker as therersquos a pastoral element to it as well. And Irsquom there for all the clubrsquos staff and their families, not just the players and the coaches. Maintaining confidences and trust is key.On a Friday I train with the players. I take part in the warm-up and then often join in with the under-s. I try to keep up with them, although I end up being the ball boy half the time. Irsquom getting old now so itrsquos still a great feeling when I can nutmeg one of the young lads. After that Irsquoll have lunch with the players and wersquoll have a bit of a chat.I usually get referred to as The Rev or Padre. One of the players even calls me Pope. Therersquos a bit of banter too and Irsquom sometimes the butt of their jokes but you just have to go along with that.Irsquom a Christian so that will always be a part of what I do. Many players have no faith or a nominal faith. Sometimes, though, in a quieter dressing room you might get a player suddenly asking, ldquoSo, Rev, what are you preaching about on Sunday  and I then have a right to answer that.Irsquod never go into a group and say, ldquoLet me tell you about Jesus, guys. When a player is injured I donrsquot go up and offer to pray for them. There are times when a player might ask me to do that. But itrsquos not about me preaching. I leave that to Sunday at church.Whenever a new player signs Irsquom over right away to introduce myself. If theyrsquove not had a chaplain at their previous club, they sometimes donrsquot know how to react. Some even stop swearing when yoursquore in their company! But with time most of them realise yoursquore just there to help themthey need it.For the first half-season or so I didnrsquot go near the players at all. I didnrsquot want the club to think I was only there because I was in awe of them. So at the start I devoted more time to talking with the staff and that was great. It got my face known and people became more comfortable with me. And at the start of the second season I had the freedom to go around the place.After month after month of seeing you around, people might come up to you and ask, ldquoRev, could I meet up with you after training in a private place  I want to chat about something thatrsquos going on with my family. And then you help them through those situations.I went on a two-day mental health training course at Hampden. That was exhausting but insightful. It also taught me how to redirect people to get proper professional helpthey need it. Sothere are health issues you make sure they get proper medical support. If itrsquos gambling there are people who specialise in that as well.Irsquove already got a full-time job so donrsquot get paid for being chaplain. This is just my service to the club. But itrsquos a lot of fun, too.Visit perthstjohnstonefc club-chaplainGRAEME MACPHERSON

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: LORD McConnell was reminiscing about the birth of Holyrood at a breakfast bash organised by thinktank Reform Scotland this week. There was the ldquomad rush to be the first MSP elected won by Tom McCabe, the first speech by Winnie Ewing and the first point of order raised by Dennis Canavan. Jack went on: ldquoSometimes people forget this, but Tommy Sheridan proposed the first private memberrsquos bill. He was a new face in Scottish politics at that time, and obviously went on to-. He paused diplomatically. ldquoTo other things.Island leHOST Chris Deerin also crowdsourced questions on Twitter. A certain ldquoNicola of Bute House asked what Jack could have done to win the  election. Spend more time on party politics, and less on being FM, he said. ldquoI tried to balance the two, but we lost by less than %, by  votes in North Ayrshire or something. Thank you, Arran. Grateful island - not. As Lord McConnell grew up on Arran, presumably the islanders knew him best.Poll: Almost three-quarters of Scots want to keep the poundLoad of shirtJACK also defended wearing his infamous striped kilt and girly blouse at a charity fashion show in the US in . His former special adviser Peter Hastie told the audience his reaction had been ldquoDear God, but Jack said he was ldquoglad people have something to laugh atldquo. They sure do. On the night, he thought it had been a great success. Alas, not for long. ldquoI went to bed in New York and at approximately .am I got a phone call from my we saying, lsquoWhat the f*** is on the front page of The Herald !rsquoCabinet furnitureWHEN Nicola Sturgeon told her cabinet about this weekrsquos big Indyref statement, she received ldquopositive feedback from ministers, her spokesman said. But what sort, panted the Holyrood hacks. Table thumping, cheers, party poppers  The spokesman gave no details. Unspun hears the same question was later put to finance secretary Derek Mackay. Nothing showy, he said. ldquoWersquore too Presbyterian. So no dancing either, then.Web wondersCOINCIDENCE fans have noted that whenever Nicola Sturgeon is moved by the national interest to pronounce on Indyref, her husband, SNP chief exec Peter Murrell, telepathically launches a new fundraising website. In March , when the FM first called Indyref, Pete instantly asked for poundm through ref.scot, and when she reset her plans that June, he started mobilise.scot to ldquobuild a better Scotland. This week, when the FM gave the handle another crank, lo and behold, Pete started rattling the cup again with yes.scot. Cynical  Surely not.Invisible letterNOT that it always go well for the psychic duo. That poundm fundraiser was suspended after massively missing its target. Rather ominously, yes.scot once belonged to Yes Scotland, the losers of . In fact, for the last four years its sole content has been a letter thanking Yessers for their efforts which referred to ldquoaccepting the result of the independence referendum. But funnily enough thatrsquos been deleted.Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueFallen branchFINALLY, Unspun hears of more trouble at the SNPrsquos most dysal branch, Coatbridge  Chryston, base of MSP Fulton MacGregor. Recent minutes state the auditors found more than % of branch spending lacked receipts - a legal requirement - a total of more than pound. The branch next meets on Wednesday. Wersquod gladly buy tickets, but we would need a receipt.

title: scotlands-greatest-drives-part-1
story: What makes it so special  Sweeping bends on a single track road, machair, wildle and walking on the moon.From Tarbert head south on the A towards Leverburgh where the first signs of the unique lunar landscape become obvious. Soon you will reach a small side road branching off to the left signposted The Golden Road, so called because its tortuous route through the intricate landscape of the Bays of Harris made it extremely expensive to build. Before its construction in the s, all traffic between the villages went either on foot or by boat.Head downhill into the village of Miabhaig which is the first of many villages you will pass through. The Golden Road winds and twists through the east coast of Harris, sometimes called the Bays because of its miniature fjords. The single track road connects all the clachans or townships, which have either Viking or Gaelic names.The best part of the route is that it is the bends are almost D and every few seconds the view changes and shows the rough side of Harris. Soyou get to the Golden Road, you see the other side of the island known for some fantastic beaches.As you wind your way along it, at no great speed, you will pass small cottage industries, local artists, crafts and traditional Harris Tweed weavers along with seals and otters relaxing on the seaweed clad rocks. Many little bays are seen on the sea side of the road and old paths are signposted for walks on these vintage ways that were the only ways before the road was build.The mixture of sea, loch, Lewisian gneiss, heather and wet green and little rounded hills makes for a striking landscape as the road winds through lochans with water lilies and bog bean in amongst the lunar rocky landscape. Its like nowhere  in Scotland.Along the way stop at the Tweed exhibition Clograve-Mograver at Drinishader, where you can see the sheds of the weavers next to many houses. The Bays of Harris has enticed many artists over the years who have been attracted by the ever changing light and complex landscape.If you fancy a break, call in at one of a number of galleries along your way ndash some have excellent cafeacutes. Just after the turn off to one of these ndash Holmasaig Gallery at Cuidhtinis ndash the road descends to the shore. Keep following the signs for Roghadal , ignoring any side roads, and once there you will find St Clementrsquos Church, perched spectacularly on a rock.Rodel was once the main town of Harris and the Skye ferry used to leave from here but now it is a tranquil harbour and many ers view Rodel as a perfect ing destination in Scotland.From here head towards Leverburgh and back onto the A towards Tarbert. On the way marvel at Luskentyre Bay, possibly the finest white beach outside the Caribbean and follow the road for the final climb of the day back over the moonscape. So alien is its appearance, the area was used by Stanley Kubrick as the surface of Jupiter in his famous film,  ndash A Space Odyssey.The climb is long and unrelenting, but eventually you will be rewarded with a tremendous sweeping descent back to Tarbert.Pit stop: Various cafes in Leverburgh, including the Butty BusALAN SIMPSONHow long   miles, three-and-a-half hoursWhat makes it so special  Driving into Scotland by the scenic routeLeft, right or middle  Left is the quickest, straight up the Afrom Carlisle . Right, via Berwick on Tweed, you wind your way along the south-east coastline, past Lindisafarne, beaches and caravans and a nuclear power station, which has its own sci-fi charm.But middle is best. Middle is the A. Middle starts in Darlington, runs up over the Tyne and rolls and bumps through rural Northumberland and then begins to climb into the Cheviot Hills until, at ftin altitude, it reaches Carter Bar on the border and suddenly Scotland is laid out in front of you.Ancient Romans, English soldiers, Scottish soldiers theyrsquove all come this way .It must have been a miserable march. But driving it is a rollercoaster of blind summits and stunning vistas and, once yoursquore in Scotland, the delights of Jedburgh and Lauder.If you have the time, detour at St Boswells to Dryburgh to see Walter Scottrsquos famous view.Pit Stop: Try Carfraemill in Lauder at the foot of the Lammermuir Hills.TEDDY JAMIESONThe Cool List:  Scottish golf courses every fan must playHow long   miles,  minutesWhat makes it so special: A scenic coastal drive with points of interest round every bend.This section of East Lothian is being branded as Scotlands Golf Coast ndash starting at the Musselburgh Links, Scotlands oldest golf club, it takes in fine links courses such as Longniddry, Gullane , Muirfield, Archerfield and North Berwick. Watch out for cyclists ndash part of this route is also the John Muir Way.Dont worryyou dont want to pack the plus-fours and the Pings ndash this short stretch has something for all the family. Starting at Musselburgh, you take the left fork down the coastand proceed through Prestonpans . You will quickly pass through Cockenzie ndash now minus the iconic twin chimneys of the recently-demolished power station ndash and Port Seton. Each boasts a picturesque harbour, and the three villages are something of an artists colony, Port Seton being the birthplace of John Bellany.Theres a fine picnic stop at Longniddry Bents, where you can exercise youngsters and empty the dog, before the traffic crawls through Aberlady and Gullane. Take a short detour to see the ruined medieval fortress of Dirleton Castlebefore ending up at North Berwick, where you can take in the beach, some bespoke shops, and marvel at how many xs can cram into such narrow streets.Pit stops: Since this is such a short drive, pit stops are best on thejourney: start with fish and chips in North Berwick and follow it with ice cream from Lucas in Musselburgh .DREW ALLANThe Cool List:  Scottish golf courses every fan must playHow long   miles but it will take all dayWhat makes it so special: Ferries and islands. Five in one day. Thats pretty special.From the ferry, turn right at Brodick and head to Sannox, where the gentle scenery and winding road from the port is replaced by open hillsides and a much faster, sweeping highway, almost devoid of traffic, with the ragged, jagged peaks of Cir Mhor in the distance. Coming down into Lochranza you pass the Arran Distillery and the ruins of Lochranza Castle, which must rank alongside Eilean Donan and Urquhart Castle for its spectacular location.From here, the ferry for Claonaig make its way across the Kilbrannan Sound to Kintyre. Then its along the narrow B onto the A. Itrsquos like a superhighway after the single track: wide, with fast, sweeping corners to Tarbert, with its pretty harbour, like something out of a Katie Morag book. Back on to the ferry, the next stop is Portavadie on the single track before it opens up towards Tighbnabruich and heads for Colintravie. Then itrsquos on to the dayrsquos shortest crossing, to Bute, which takes less than three minutes, then along to Rothesay and onto the fth and final ferry to Wemyss Bay.Some of the roads are poorly surfaced but that doesnt matter. This is a route to take in the scenery, the castles, wildle, lochs and, of course, the sea views.Pit stops: The Sandwich Stop at Lochranza is the perfect place for a piece. They also do artisanal sandwichesand soups and coffees.GARRY SCOTTTornapress to Applecross, Wester RossHow long   miles, around  minutesWhat makes it so special  Hairpin bends and the promise of a seafood feast.It may not seem very far on the map, yet this drive packs a punch, traversing Bealach na Ba ndash a winding, single-track road through the mountains of the Applecross peninsula ndash complete with hairpin bends, jaw-dropping views and plentul nature sightings.Starting from near sea-level at Tornapress next to Loch Kishorn, the road rises to ftin . milesof climbing, reaching  per cent at its steepest gradient. There is a viewpoint at the top with panoramas across to Skye and beyond on a clear day.You may not want to hang about too long as the reward of a hearty feed awaits at the Applecross Inn once you descend the other side.Pit stop: Grab coffee and cake at the Bealach Cafe in Tornapress but save room for a pint of prawns at the Applecross Inn.SUSAN SWARBRICKCircuit from Spittal of Glenshee, Perth and Kinross.How long  Approx  miles, four days .What makes it so special  If you have already driven the hugely popular North Coast  or you are a looking for a quieter destination, the North East  is an ideal alternative for a multi-day driving route.The circuit heads through the north-east of Scotland, visiting the Cairngorms, Speyside, Moray, Aberdeenshire and Royal Deeside. Famous for its drier and sunnier climate, the north-east also delivers with a fantastic ersity of landscapes, from majestic mountains and wild moorlands to glorious glens, rocky coastlines and pristine beaches.The  miles could be driven in one day although that would be missing the point of such a great journey. Instead, four days to a week allows you to stop at numerous attractions, including castles, heritage centres, distilleries, golf courses and nature reserves.A suggested starting point is Spittal of Glenshee in the Cairngorms National Park. Travelling clockwise, day one will take you to Aberlour in the heart of whisky country. There are plenty of visitor sites including two mountain resorts, Glenshee and The Lecht Ballindalloch Castle the distilleries of Glenlivet and Aberlour and a walk to Linn Falls.Day two heads north to meet the coast at Spey Bay before turning east to reach the seaside town of Banff. Mountain vistas turn to rolling farmland and then the fabulous Moray coastline.Spey Bay is famous for dolphin watching, while a string of pretty shoreline villages, including Findochty, Portnockie, Cullen and Portsoy, are recommended for a stop-and-stroll.Take a walk along a section of the Moray Coast Trail and marvel at rock formations called Bow Fiddle and Whalersquos Mouth and visit the atmospheric ruins of Findlater Castle.From Banff, day three will take you to towards Aberdeen for a suggested overnight at Maryculter. In the far north-east corner is the fishing town of Fraserburgh, home to a vast expanse of sandy beach and the fascinating Museum of Scottish Lighthouses. Further south are other highlights, including the natural phenomenon of Bullers of Buchan, Cruden Bay and Slains Castle.On day four, the NE heads west again through Royal Deeside, where the attractions came thick and fast. The castles of Crathes, Balmoral and Braemar beckon, or why not park the car and take a walk into the countryside for yet more wonderful views of hills, mountains and the winding River Dee Pit stop: Treat yourself to a cone at award-winning Portsoy Ice Cream, enjoy a dram at the Quaich Bar at Craigellachie Hotel and dine at highly rated Rothesay Rooms, Ballater.FIONA RUSSELLThe Cool List:The Best Scottish Railway JourneysHow long   miles, around  minutesWhat makes it so special  Steep climbs and sweeping descents.This drive begins with the steady climb out of Lennoxtown on the hallowed Crow Road . As you near the end of the first stretch, it is worth pulling over to enjoy the views for a few moments from what is dubbed ldquothe car park in the sky.Continue up through the Campsies towards the summit and then follow the sweeping road back down towards Fintry. Itrsquos a popular route for cyclists so do take care and give them space.From Fintry continue on the B where you will reach a turn-off and head left for Arnprior or straight on for Kippin.Both routes offer pretty scenery but via Arnprior is shorter as the crow flies to meet the B which runs past Lake of Menteithand Inchmahome Priory. Turn left onto the A and follow signs for Aberfoyle.Pit stop: The Courtyard Cafe, Knockraich Farm, Fintry is home to a coffee shop and artisan dairy. Be sure to try the farm-made ice cream.SUSAN SWARBRICKHow long   milesdepending on the route, allow - hoursWhat makes it so special  Neolithic monuments and stunning landscapesTo be honest, there is no one set route to follow on the Orkney mainland. Rather prepare for a magical mystery tour as you venture off the main roads to scoot along B routes and single-tracks.Head west out of Kirkwall along the A to the junction for the A. From here head north and follow the road in an anti-clockwise direction around the mainland. It is a pretty drive with plenty of points of interest, not least an opportunity is to visit the iron age Broch of Gurness near Evie.The Neolithic monuments at Orkneyrsquos heart ndash Skara Brae, Maeshowe, Ring of Brodgar and Standing Stones of Stenness ndash are within easy driving distance. Built , years ago, this former settlement, large chambered tomb and two ceremonial stone circles form a Unesco World Heritage Centre.On the west of the mainland is Yesnaby with its towering sandstone clfs and majestic sea stack which is a wonderful spot to watch the sunset. Heading south, the turn off is on the right, around a third of a mile before the junction where the B meets the A.No visit to Orkney would be complete without driving over the Churchill Barriers, a series of four causeways linking the mainland to the islands of Lamb Holm, Glims Holm, Burray and South Ronaldsay.Lamb Holm is home to the Italian Chapel, built from two old Nissen huts by prisoners-of-war in . Continue south across Glims Holm and Burray towards the farthest tip of South Ronaldsay and the Tomb of the Eagles, a Neolithic chambered tomb located on a clf edge.Pit stop: Gerrirsquos Ice Cream Parlour, Stenness. Try the monster cone with seven scoopsyou dare.SUSAN SWARBRICKHow long   miles, one hourA bit unusual, this, but it will allow you to indulge your Colin McRae rally driver fantasies ndash albeit at a much slower pace.This forest drive takes you through the woodlands of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park on a quiet forest road from March to October. Beware, its bumpy going.The route, which costs pound, is one-way and takes you past three lochs ndash Lochan Reoidhte, Loch Drunkie and Loch Achray.The entrance is on the Ajust north of Aberfoyle. There are several car parks on the route as well as picnic areas and short walking trails.Pitstop: The Lodge Forest visitor ventre on the A has a cafe, walks, a shop and also the Go Ape aerial adventure trail. The Brig o Turk Tea Room is a charming spot for a coffee and a cake.GARRY SCOTTDays Out: Scotlands top  beachesHow long   miles, a nice half-hour drive hellip but there are so many places to stop, best leave a full afternoon.What makes it so special  The unexpected, off-the-beaten-track beauty.The sign just past Pitlochry heading north on the A is unassuming ndash "Clunie , Foss " ndash but the road itself is an absolute joy. This little single-track route to Tummel Bridge, along the south side of Loch Faskally and Loch Tummel, takes you to places that you may not have seen before, but which you will never forget. Leave an hour at least to explore the Linn of Tummel ndash an amazing gorge where this grand river is pushed into a series of boiling pots and waterfalls check out Clunie Dam ndash a properly wild feat of engineering at the foot of Loch Tummel stoplong the lochside to marvel at the views.At Tummel Bridge, you have a choice hellip go back to your starting point along the usual, north side of the Loch , or head into the mountains, past Schiehallion and down into Tayside. A real treat either way.Pit stop: Take a picnic hellip yoursquoll be glad you did!ANDY CLARK. The Beatles: Drive My Car DECIDEDLY about more than merely driving a car, as becomes clear from the lyrics: "Baby you can drive my car  Yes Im gonna be a star  Baby you can drive my car  And maybe Ill love you." One of the highlights of the Fab Fours Rubber Soul LP.. The Stills Young Band: Long May You Run, PLAINTIVE tribute, on album by Neil Young and occasional cohort Stephen Stills, about Youngs first-ever car, a  Buick Roadmaster hearse. "Well, it was back in Blind River in   When I last saw you alive  But we missed that sht on the long decline  Long may you run...". The Beach Boys: Little Deuce Coupe FROM the classic album of the same name. "Like many of rocks early artistic statements, [the album] was inspired by a subject of teenage fascination, in this case the hot-rod phenomenon," says Ultimate Classic Rock magazine. Sample lyric: "Well Im not braggin babe so dont put me down  But Ive got the fastest set of wheels in town.". Wilson Pickett: Mustang Sally PICKETTS great version of this classic hit made it into Rolling Stone magazines poll of the  greatest songs of all time. The Commitments recorded it in the early s. "Mustang Sally, think you better slow your mustang down  You been running all over the town now.". The Eagles: Ol  TOM Waits, author of this song, has often spoken about his love of old cars. He disliked the Eagles "antiseptic" version, but that version, with its gorgeous harmonies and pedal steel, deservedly reached a vast audience.. Tom Robinson Band: --- Motorway Great pop single about the joys of night-time driving. "Drive my truck midway to the motorway station  Fairlane cruiser coming up on the left-hand side  Headlight shining, driving rain on the window frame..."Scotland has topped a list of the worldrsquos most beautul countries as voted by Rough Guides readers. Herersquos how to make the most of your trip. Drive slower and smarter. Your vehicle will get better fuel efficiency and emit fewer greenhouse gases by avoiding hard accelerations or slamming on the brakes. Remove heavy items, roof racks and bike carriers when not in use. Check tyres regularly:they are under-inflated, this can reduce fuel efficiency and release more harmful pollutants into the air. Donrsquot let environmentally-friendly habits slip when you travel. Recycle, avoid products with unnecessary packaging and take litter home with you. Eat local produce and support homegrown businesses that prioritise responsible sourcing, manufacturing and recycled materials. If staying overnight consider eco-friendly accommodation such as hotels, hostels, lodges, cottages and cabins with carbon neutral footprints. Stick to the path. If you are out walking or hiking, it may seem harmless to take a short cut off sign-posted routes, but it could be that yoursquore treading unnecessarily through the delicate ecosystem of protected or endangered plants and animals.

title: umi-japanese-cuisine-deanhaugh-street-edinburgh-reviewed-by-ron-mackenna
story: EdinburghOK, itrsquos not quite the Seven Levels of The Candy Cane Forest but for a restaurant the size of a shoe Umi Japanese Cuisine here packs a high level of confusing kitsch into a pretty tight space.Let me put you in the picture. Irsquove bounded down the steps, through the sticky front door and on past the people sitting in what looks like a giant window box with rice paper .Now Irsquom standing awkwardly in a between-raised-tables channel under quaint market-stall roofing while Edinburgh folk look and frown and I swither about whether to go all the way back and pull that door tight shut again. For them. I get it. Itrsquos cold out. Or go on underneath the hanging lanterns, past the fairground-style booth and round a corner into the next room to seeI can find someone who actually works here.Umm, I shut the front door again, properly this time. Then press on towards the Sea of Swirly Twirly Chinese Lanterns and just as I reach the corner a waiter comes running, literally.OK, any speed above excuse me in here looks like running, but he is simultaneously moving and apologising and sitting me at a tiny table which is about the only one in the whole place not under a hanging lamp. And also revealing there are terrible staff-shortages tonight and he has to serve all these peopleby himself. Andhellipwait for thishellipmake all the ramen too.Crikey, I think, looking towards the door. Suddenly itrsquos a very long way away. Too bloody far to run. We establish importantly anyway that there are definitely chefs in the kitchen and I settle in for a long wait. Which simply doesnrsquot happen. Actually, and within, say, a few minutes Irsquom eating from a sweet little bowl of edamame beans and whole chillies tossed in a wok, seasoned with salt and covered with something tasting real good that looks like fried multi-coloured straw.Joanna Blythmans restaurant review: One Square,  Festival Square, EdinburghIs this straw stuff onion and chilli, I ask a waitress who has suddenly appeared to help out. She peers deep into the gloomand announces: itrsquos too dark, I canrsquot see it.Ah, by now anyway Irsquom half way through a pound. six-piece negi toro futomaki, aka seaweed wrapped sushi roll made from ldquothe best part of bluefin tuna tartare with spring onion, shisho and shallots. This from a menu emblazoned with the words: Todayrsquos Special.I have got to say, it does not look like today is this printed menursquos first day in action. Or even close.Whatever, the tuna is plump and pink and pleasantly fresh . And Irsquove been distracted again. Goruden cod finger, made with katai pastry ndash which I thought was actually Greek. This is sitting at the table looking like three giant shredded wheat fingers, one of which is rudely stuffed in a glass of what looks like cocktail sauce but is actually, er, mango mayo. Frankly  Not for me.The sickly mango mayo may just be the accidental reinvention of a Mr Men Yoghurt, and the shredded wheat pastry tastes like fried shredded wheat, and while there is some promised Scottish cod deep inside itrsquos so outgunned by everything  it was pointless even showing up.Fortunately, and just as the remnants of this are being dragged off in shame, my original waiter is back from his ramen booth and is asking what I think of the Crazy Tonkotsu Ramen. Which he just made. Himself.The broth is cooked for  hours, he proudly reminds me, as I slide head-first into slippy, slurpy, soupy-land of pork slices, seaweed sheets and jalapeno strands, all underpinned by a very good, creamily smooth, properly seasoned stock and just the right chilli tingle.Umi Japanese Cuisine then  Mad but definitely not bad. I cant help really liking this place.Joanna Blythmans restaurant review: One Square,  Festival Square, EdinburghUmi Japanese Cuisine Deanhaugh StreetEdinburgh  Menu: Crazy kitschy mix of Japanese staples, proper sushi, interesting ramen, -hour broths and those goruden cod fingers.  Service: Full marks for being honest about staff shortages which actually made no dference as the service was swt, pleasant and warm.  Price: The Crazy Ramen signature dish was almost pound, the excellent shishito peppers pound.. Overall reasonable.  Atmosphere: Frankly, itrsquos a bit mad inside with a multi-level assault on the senses but nothingnot buzzing and busy.  Food: I didnrsquot take to the goruden cod things, but very good ramen and excellent plate of chilli and edamame. Crisp, clean cooking.
